bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person appointed as committee under section 6 (1);
the Public Guardian and Trustee under section 6 (3);

bcl:text.#text: a statutory property guardian under Part 2.1 of the ;

a person who, before paragraph (a.1) of this definition comes into force, was described in a certificate signed by the director of a Provincial mental health facility or psychiatric unit as defined in the  as one who is, because of mental infirmity arising from disease, age or otherwise, incapable of managing his or her affairs,
a person who has a statutory property guardian under Part 2.1 of the , or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who is declared under this Act by a judge to be

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: incapable of managing his or her affairs,
incapable of managing himself or herself, or
incapable of managing himself or herself or his or her affairs;

bcl:text.#text:
means the Public Guardian and
          Trustee holding office under the ;

means an agreement made under the
            .

bcl:text:
The Attorney General, a near relative of a person or other person may apply to the
          court for an order declaring that a person is, because of

incapable of managing his or her affairs or incapable of managing himself or
          herself, or incapable of managing himself or herself or his or her affairs.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mental infirmity arising from disease, age or otherwise, or
disorder or disability of mind arising from the use of drugs,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subject to subsection (3), a notice setting out the time and place of the application
          must be served personally on the person who is the subject of the application not less
          than 10 days before the date of the application.
On an application under this section, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: direct that any person be served with notice of the application, or
dispense with service on any person of notice of the application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Despite subsection (3), unless the court is satisfied that service on the person who
          is the subject of the application would be injurious to that person's health or would for
          any other reason be inadvisable in the interests of that person, the court must not
          dispense with service on that person.

bcl:text: If, on
the court is satisfied that the person is, because of

incapable of managing his or her affairs or incapable of managing himself or
          herself, or incapable of managing himself or herself or his or her affairs, it must, by
          order, declare the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hearing an application, and

bcl:text:
reading the affidavits of 2 medical practitioners setting out their opinion that
            the person who is the subject of the application is, because of

incapable of managing his or her affairs or incapable of managing himself or
            herself, or incapable of managing himself or herself or his or her affairs,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: mental infirmity arising from disease, age or otherwise, or
disorder or disability of mind arising from the use of drugs,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mental infirmity arising from disease, age or otherwise, or
disorder or disability of mind arising from the use of drugs,
incapable of managing his or her affairs,
incapable of managing himself or herself, or
incapable of managing himself or herself or his or her affairs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The court may, on hearing an application under this section and reading the
          affidavits described in subsection (1), direct an issue to be tried, and in that
          event the following provisions apply:

bcl:text:
the question in issue is whether the person who is the subject of the
            application is, because of

incapable of managing his or her affairs or incapable of managing himself or
            herself, or incapable of managing himself or herself or his or her affairs;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: mental infirmity arising from disease, age or otherwise, or
disorder or disability of mind arising from the use of drugs,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this Act applies to the issue and the trial of it;
the Supreme Court Civil Rules apply;
the court must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
by order, declare that the person who is the subject of the
              application

bcl:clause.bcl:text: is incapable of managing his or her affairs,
is incapable of managing himself or herself, or

is incapable of managing himself or herself or his or her
                affairs.

bcl:text.#text: The rights to reassessment and review set out in sections 34 and 35 of the  apply, and section 37 (3) and (4) of that Act applies, to a patient as defined in paragraph (a) of the definition of "patient" under this Act as if
the patient is an adult with a statutory property guardian under the ,
the patient's committee is a statutory property guardian under the ,

the director of a Provincial mental health facility or psychiatric unit who signed the certificate referred to in paragraph (a) of the definition of "patient" under this Act, or a person acting on his or her behalf or who is his or her successor, is the health authority designate referred to in the ,
the certificate referred to in paragraph (a) of the definition of "patient" under this Act is a certificate of incapability issued under section 32 of the , and

for the purposes of section 35 (2) (b) of the , the body that appointed the director who signed the certificate referred to in paragraph (a) of the definition of "patient" under this Act is a party to a review.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: [Not in force.]

bcl:text.#text: if statutory property guardianship ends under section 37 (3) of the , the person ceases to be a patient.

For greater certainty, the rights to reassessment and review set out in sections 34 and 35, and section 37 (3) and (4), of the  continue to apply to a patient as defined in paragraph (a.1) of the definition of "patient".

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Order declaring person no longer incapable

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies only to patients as defined in paragraph (b) of the definition of "patient".

At any time after one year from the making of an order under section 3 or sooner
          by leave of the court, the Attorney General, the patient or other person may apply to the
          court for an order declaring that a patient is no longer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: incapable of managing his or her affairs,
incapable of managing himself or herself, or
incapable of managing himself or herself or his or her affairs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Except by leave of the court, a patient must not be the subject of an application
          under this subsection more often than once in any year.

bcl:text: If, on
the court is satisfied that the patient is no longer
the court may, by order, so declare.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hearing an application under this section, and

reading the affidavits of 2 medical practitioners setting out their opinion that
            the patient is no longer

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: incapable of managing his or her affairs,
incapable of managing himself or herself, or
incapable of managing himself or herself or his or her affairs,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: incapable of managing his or her affairs,
incapable of managing himself or herself, or
incapable of managing himself or herself or his or her affairs,

bcl:text: If

the court hearing the appeal or application or trying the issue may order the
          person who is the subject of the application or the patient to attend and submit at the
          time and place the order directs to examination.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application is made or an issue is tried under section 3,
an appeal is taken from an order under section 3, or
an application is made under section 4,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An examination under this section must be made by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
one or more medical practitioners other than those whose affidavits were before
            the court on the appeal, application or trial, or

a board of 3 or more medical practitioners designated by the College of
            Physicians and Surgeons of British Columbia at the request of the court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the person who is the subject of the application or the patient requests an
          examination under this section, unless the court hearing the appeal or application is
          satisfied that the person or patient is not mentally competent to form and express the
          request, the court must order the examination.

Subject to section 13, on application by the Attorney General or
          any other person, the court may appoint any person to be the committee of the
          patient.

On application by the Attorney General, the Public Guardian and Trustee or any
          other person, the court may, subject to section 13, rescind the appointment of a person
          appointed as committee.

Subject to section 16, except during the time that a person
          appointed under subsection (1), other than the Public Guardian and Trustee, is the
          committee of a patient, the Public Guardian and Trustee is the committee of the
          patient.

An application under subsection (1) and an application under section 2 may be made
          as one application.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Service of notice of application to appoint committee
bcl:section.bcl:text:
Notice in writing of an application to appoint a committee must be served, not less
        than 10 days before the date of the application, on

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Public Guardian and Trustee, and
the committee of the patient if one has been appointed.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
If the court appoints a committee to succeed another committee, the former
        committee, on being discharged under section 13,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ceases to be the committee of the patient, and
must transfer the estate of the patient to the appointed committee.

bcl:text:
On an application for the appointment of a committee, if there is presented to the
        court a nomination in writing of a committee by the patient,

the nominee must be appointed committee unless there is good and sufficient reason
        for refusing the appointment.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
made and signed by the patient at a time when the patient was of full age and of
          sound and disposing mind, and

bcl:text.#text:
executed in accordance with the requirements for the making of a will under the
            ,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If a committee other than the Public Guardian and Trustee has been appointed under
          this Act, the following rules apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
if property belonging to the patient is discovered after the first passing of
            accounts under paragraph (d) and that property is valued at $25 000 or more, the
            committee must, within 30 days of the discovery of the property, deliver to the Public
            Guardian and Trustee a true account of the property as it is discovered;

if ordered by the court, either on the person's appointment as committee or
            subsequently on the application of the Public Guardian and Trustee, the committee must
            give security for the proper performance of the committee's duties in the amount the
            court directs in the form of a bond that must be in the name of the Public Guardian and
            Trustee, approved by the Registrar of the Supreme Court, and filed with the Public
            Guardian and Trustee;

the committee must pass the committee's accounts before the Public Guardian and
            Trustee at the times directed by the Public Guardian and Trustee, including, if the
            Public and Guardian Trustee requires it, a true inventory of the whole estate of the
            patient, stating the estimated revenue of it and setting out the debts, credits and
            effects of the patient to the extent they have come to the knowledge of the
            committee;

if required by the Public Guardian and Trustee, the committee must pass the
            accounts before the Supreme Court in the county in which the committee was appointed
            committee.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A committee may at any time appeal the passing of accounts by the Public Guardian
          and Trustee to the Supreme Court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When a person ceases to be a patient

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person ceases to be a patient on any of the following events:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: [Repealed 2014-9-33.]
the making of an order declaring that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the patient is no longer incapable of managing his or her affairs,

the patient is no longer incapable of managing himself or herself,
              or

the patient is no longer incapable of managing himself or herself or his or
              her affairs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: [Repealed 2014-9-33.]

Despite anything in this Act to the contrary, the Public Guardian and Trustee may
          carry out and complete a transaction entered into by the Public Guardian and Trustee in
          relation to a patient's estate which is not completed before the patient ceases to be a
          patient.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
If a person ceases to be a patient, the person or the committee of the person's
        estate other than the Public Guardian and Trustee may apply, on 10 days' notice in writing
        to the Public Guardian and Trustee, to the court for the discharge of the
        committee.

bcl:text: If

the court may, and must if requested by the Public Guardian and Trustee, order
          that the committee pass the accounts and may, in the order, specify the time and the
          manner of passing the accounts, and must adjourn the application until the carrying out of
          the order.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
an application is made under section 12 for the discharge of a committee other than
            the Public Guardian and Trustee, or

an application is made for the rescission of the appointment of a committee
            other than the Public Guardian and Trustee,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If a committee fails to pass the accounts as ordered, or if the accounts are found
          to be incomplete or inaccurate, the committee may be required to attend before the court
          to explain why the accounts have not been passed or a proper proceeding in connection with
          them taken, and the court may give the direction it considers proper.

After the order made under subsection (1) has been carried out, and the court is
          satisfied that no further passing of accounts is necessary, the court may order that the
          committee is discharged.

If the Public Guardian and Trustee or a committee is discharged under this
          section, the Public Guardian and Trustee or the committee

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
has no further powers or duties with respect to the estate of the person who has
            ceased to be a patient, and

is released, except in respect of undisclosed acts, neglects, defaults or
            accounts or dishonest or unlawful conduct, from all actions, claims and demands for or
            concerning the Public Guardian and Trustee's or the committee's management or
            administration of the estate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A person may be allowed reasonable compensation from the estate of a patient or
          from the estate of a person who has ceased to be a patient for services rendered as
          committee of the patient or of the person who has ceased to be a patient.

The compensation, if any, to be paid to a person other than the Public Guardian
          and Trustee must be fixed on the passing of accounts.

If, in the opinion of a person who is entitled to compensation under this section,
          the estate of a patient or the estate of a person who has ceased to be a patient is so
          limited in value that the payment out of it of compensation would create poverty or
          hardship for the patient or person who has ceased to be a patient or the patient's
          dependants, no compensation need be claimed or paid or no amount need be retained out of
          the estate.

A committee of a patient or a person who has been the committee of a person who
          has ceased to be a patient has a first lien or charge on the estate of the patient or
          person who has ceased to be a patient for all costs, expenses and advances made by him or
          her for or incidental to the administration of the estate of the patient or the person who
          has ceased to be a patient or for the benefit of the patient or person who has ceased to
          be a patient, the patient's family or other dependants.
Subject to section 16,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the committee of a patient as defined in paragraph (a) or (a.1) of the definition of "patient" in section 1 has all the rights, privileges and powers with regard to the estate
            of the patient as the patient would have if of full age and of sound and disposing mind,
            and
the committee of a patient

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
declared to be incapable of managing his or her affairs has all the rights,
              privileges and powers with regard to the estate of the patient as the patient would
              have if of full age and of sound and disposing mind,

declared to be incapable of managing himself or herself has the custody of the
              person of the patient, and

declared to be incapable of managing himself or herself or his or her affairs
              has all the rights, privileges and powers with regard to the estate of the patient as
              the patient would have if of full age and of sound and disposing mind, and as well the
              custody of the person of the patient.

bcl:text.#text: For investing money, a committee is a trustee within the meaning of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special direction limiting powers of committee

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
On the appointment of a committee, the court may, by the same order, attach
          conditions or restrictions on the committee's exercise of certain rights, privileges or
          powers specified in the order, including requiring the written consent of the Public
          Guardian and Trustee prior to the committee's exercise of any right, privilege or
          power.

If, under subsection (1), the court has attached a condition that the consent of the
          Public Guardian and Trustee is required prior to the committee's exercise of any right,
          privilege or power, the registrar of the court must send a copy of the court's order to
          the Public Guardian and Trustee.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
The rights, powers and privileges vested in the committee include all the rights,
        powers and privileges that would be exercisable by the patient as a trustee, as the guardian
        of a person, as the holder of a power of appointment and as the personal representative of a
        person, if the person were of full age and of sound and disposing mind.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A committee must exercise the committee's powers for the benefit of the patient and
        the patient's family, having regard to the nature and value of the property of the patient
        and the circumstances and needs of the patient and the patient's family.
A committee must, to the extent reasonable, foster the independence of the patient and encourage the patient's involvement in any decision making that affects the patient.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Effect on power of attorney or representation agreement of person becoming a
        patient by court order
bcl:section.bcl:text:
On a person becoming a patient as defined in paragraph (b) of the definition of
        "patient" in section
          1,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: every power of attorney given by the person is terminated, and

unless the court orders otherwise, every representation agreement made by the
          person is terminated.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Effect on power of attorney or certain representation agreements of person
        becoming a patient other than by court order

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
On a person becoming a patient as defined in paragraph (a) or (a.1) of the definition of
          "patient" in section 1, the following are suspended:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: every power of attorney that was given by the person;

every provision of a representation agreement made by the person in respect of
            his or her property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
After receiving a copy of the suspended power of attorney or of a representation
          agreement any provision of which has been suspended under subsection (1) and any information
          that the Public Guardian and Trustee may require, the Public Guardian and Trustee must
          determine whether it is necessary or desirable for the Public Guardian and Trustee to
          manage the patient's property under this Act.

bcl:text:
If the Public Guardian and Trustee determines that it is necessary or desirable
          for the Public Guardian and Trustee to manage the patient's property, then on the making
          of the determination
as the case may be.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the power of attorney that was suspended under subsection (1) is terminated,
            or

the provisions of the representation agreement that were suspended under
              subsection
              (1) are cancelled,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the Public Guardian and Trustee determines that it is not necessary or
          desirable for the Public Guardian and Trustee to manage the patient's property,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the Public Guardian and Trustee's authority as committee  is
            terminated on the making of that determination, and

the suspension of the power of attorney or of the provisions of the
            representation agreement ends on the termination of the Public Guardian and Trustee's
            authority as committee.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of things done by committee
bcl:section.bcl:text:
Everything done by a committee in the exercise of the committee's powers under this
        Act has the same effect with respect to all other persons as if done by the patient at a
        time when the patient was of full age and of sound and disposing mind.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A person other than the committee of the patient must not bring an action on
          behalf of the patient.

An action against a patient must be brought against the committee as litigation
          guardian.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Cost of maintenance, care and treatment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A patient is liable for the cost of the patient's maintenance, care and treatment
          and, subject to section 18, the committee must pay out of the estate of the patient the
          amounts necessary to defray all just and reasonable charges for the maintenance, care and
          treatment of the patient.

The Public Guardian and Trustee may permit a patient of whose estate the Public
          Guardian and Trustee is committee to hold, manage or control a part of the estate to
          defray normal living expenses or part of them, and the Public Guardian and Trustee is not
          liable for loss or damage to the estate of the patient resulting from the patient holding,
          managing or controlling that part of the estate.

bcl:text.#text:
Subject to subsection (2), on the death of a patient and until
          a
          representation grant, within the meaning of the , is issued in respect of the patient's
          estate and notice in writing of the
          representation
          grant is served on the committee, the committee of the patient

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
continues to have the rights, powers, duties and privileges that the committee
            would have had if the patient had not died, and

has the powers of a person who has been issued a representation
            grant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Despite section 10 (1) (d), the Public Guardian and Trustee must not require the
          committee to pass accounts before the Public Guardian and Trustee after the death of the
          patient.

After the death of the patient, the committee must provide the committee's
          accounts to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the executor or administrator of the patient's estate, or

if the committee and the executor or administrator of the patient's estate are
            the same person, the beneficiaries of the patient's estate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The executor, administrator or beneficiaries of the patient's estate may provide
          to the committee written approval of, and consent to, the accounts received under
          subsection (3).

If a committee fails to provide its accounts as required under subsection
          (3), or if the accounts are incomplete or inaccurate, a person entitled to the
          accounts may require the committee to attend before the court to explain the committee's
          failure to provide the accounts or to provide a satisfactory accounting, and the court may
          give the direction it considers proper.

The court may, on being satisfied that no further accounting by the committee is
          necessary, order at any time that the committee is discharged.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
The costs of all proceedings under this Act are in the discretion of the
        court.

If there is insufficient provision in this Act, the court may at any time, on the
        application of any person, make an order not in contradiction to this Act or the regulations
        that it considers necessary for or in the interests of the proper, honest and prudent
        management and administration of the estate of a patient.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appointment of new Public Guardian and Trustee

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If a new Public Guardian and Trustee is appointed, the new Public Guardian and
          Trustee is committee to every patient of whom the predecessor was the
          committee.

If a person resident in another province who would be, if resident in British
          Columbia, a patient as defined under this Act has estate in British Columbia, the
          Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint the person who is charged with the duty of
          managing, handling, administering or caring for the estate of that person in that province
          to be the committee of the estate of the person in British Columbia.

The order in council making an appointment under subsection (1) is conclusive
          evidence that all conditions precedent to the appointment have been fulfilled.

bcl:text: Every person appointed a committee under subsection (1)

and this Act applies to the person in the same manner as to the Public Guardian
          and Trustee acting as the committee of the estate of the person.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
has as committee in respect to the estate of the person in British Columbia the
            same rights, powers, privileges and immunities as are conferred by this Act on the
            Public Guardian and Trustee as committee of a patient in British Columbia,
            and
is subject to the same obligations and must perform the same duties

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
All acts of a person appointed committee under this section are binding in all
          courts and land title offices in the same manner and to the same extent as the acts of the
          Public Guardian and Trustee acting as the committee of the estate of a patient are
          binding.
